questions: Q. 1. What does the stationary phase of sigmoid growth curve indicate?
answers: Ans. The stationary phase of sigmoid growth curve indicates the phase of slow growth which finally stops.

questions: Q. 2. What is meant by development?
answers: Ans. Development is the sequence of events that occur in the life history of a cell, organ or organism, which includes growth, differentiation, maturation and senescence.

questions: Q. 3. Why do leaves shed seasonally?
answers: Ans. Because production of auxin is stopped by leaves.

questions: Q. 4. What is real growth?
answers: Ans. The growth that involves formation of new protoplasm is called as real growth.

questions: Q. 5. Name the three phases of growth?
answers: Ans. Meristematic, elongation and maturation Phase.

questions: Q. 6. Name the factors which affect growth and development of plants
answers: Ans. The factors that affect growth and development of plants are : Light, temperature, oxygen carbon dioxide, water, soil minerals and growth regulators.

questions: Q. 7. What is growth curve
answers: Ans. It is the graphic representation of the total growth against time.

questions: Q. 8. What is grand period of growth ?
answers: Ans. The period or time, in which growth takes place, has been called grand period of growth.

questions: Q. 9. Name any one hormone which increases femaleness in plants.
answers: Ans. Auxins, cytokinins, ethylene.

questions: Q. 10. How light affects germination in pea and onion seeds?
answers: Ans. In pea seeds germination is hastened by the presence of light. Light inhibits germination of the seeds of onion.

questions: Q. 11. Name the plant hormone that can delay senescence.
answers: Ans. Cytokinin is the plant hormone that can delay senescence.

questions: Q. 12. Name the only gaseous natural plant growth regulator.
answers: Ans. The only gaseous natural plant growth regulator is ethylene (CH2 = CH2).

questions: Q. 13. Name the PGR that is used in brewing industry.
answers: Ans. Gibberellic acid (GA3).

questions: Q. 14. Give the role of Ethephon.
answers: Ans. Ethephon hastens fruit ripening in apples and tomatoes.

questions: Q. 15. A plant placed near a window grows and bends towards the source of light. Give one reason.
answers: Ans. It is because that auxin migrates from bright side of the tip to the darken side of the tip.

questions: Q. 16. Why do leaves shed seasonally?
answers: Ans. Because production of auxin is stopped by leaves.

questions: Q. 17. What is bolting ?
answers: Ans. Enormous elongation of internodes results in increase in stem height.

questions: Q. 18. How do gibberellins promotes seed germination?
answers: Ans. (i) Long day plants-Wheat, Cabbage. (ii) Short day plants-Rice, Potato. (iii) Day neutral plants-Balsam, Tomato.

questions: Q. 20. Which hormone promotes leaf fall?
answers: Ans. Abscisic acid promotes leaf fall.

questions: Q. 21. What does apical dominance mean?
answers: Ans. Suppression of the growth of lateral buds/ branches is called apical dominance.

questions: Q. 22. Name the growth substance which causes senescence.
answers: Ans. Abscisic acid.

questions: Q. 23. Which is the site for the synthesis of florigen?
answers: Ans. Leaves are the sites for the synthesis of florigen.

questions: Q. 24. Define senescence.
answers: Ans. Senescence is the process by which cells irreversibly stop dividing and enter a state of permanent growth arrest without under-going cell death.

questions: Q. 25. Which wavelength of light is most active in its effect on flowering?
answers: Ans. Wavelength of red light is most active in its effect on flowering.

questions: Q. 26. What are photoblastic seeds?
answers: Ans. Seeds which require light for germination are known as photoblastic seeds.

questions: Q. 27. What is etiolation?
answers: Ans. Weak, pale, slender stems with small yellow leaves is termed as etiolation.

questions: Q. 28. Name the substance which is capable of transmitting vernalising stimulus.
answers: Ans. Vernalin is the substance which is capable of transmitting vernalising stimulus.

questions: Q. 29. What is florigen?
answers: Ans. Growth hormone inducing flowering in plants is called as florigen. It helps in overcoming apical dominance.

questions: Q. 30. What is kinetin?
answers: Ans. Kinetin is a substance which promotes cell division (cytokinesis).

questions: Q. 31. Name the auxin used as a weedicide.
answers: Ans. 2, 4-D and 2, 4, 5-T.

questions: Q. 32. What is respiratory climactic?
answers: Ans. Ethylene enhances the respiration rate during ripening of the fruits. This rise in rate of respiration is called respiratory climactic.
